Hurd, Conrad. 2008. ISO 639-3 Code Change Request 2007-188. , Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: The ISO 639-3 code [cqd], 'Chuanqiandian Cluster Miao', seems to cover a variety of dialects which overlap with those covered by other codes, such as [hnj] and [mww]. For this reason, the code [cqd] is excluded from this tree and only appears in the form of dialect codes which haven't been found to fall under other official ISO codes. It should also be noted that there are many overlapping names in this section of Hmongic, due to the various ethnolinguistic groups' Hmong autonyms, Chinese exonyms, and the English translations of each. For this reason, it is possible that some of the dialects listed here refer to the same lect, or conversely, that a single dialect actually encompasses multiple dialects. It is also unclear whether these are best described as languages or dialects, as the literature on Hmong-Mien varies in terminology.
